abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Quality Education for
            All Program (QEFA) for Senegal were as follows: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Following are lessons learned from the project:
            Harmonization of donors' procedures is an important
            condition for the successful implementation of a sector-wide
            program. The government's commitment is essential for
            the implementation of an education sector program. The Bank
            is still having difficulties to implement successful reform
            in higher education in Senegal. It is extremely difficult to
            have a precise planning of an entire sector, especially in a
            context where the information system is weak. The program
            was implemented fully through Government's departments,
            which has resulted in considerably strengthening ownership
            during the implementation of the program and also allowing
            the education sector to develop strong capacities, notably
            in fiduciary management at the central and deconcentrated
            levels. The implementation of the first phase of QEFA
            suffered from conflicts between Educational Planning and
            Reform Department (DPRE) in charge of the coordination and
            education directorates because of a lack of clearly
            hierarchical relationship established between them.
            Outsourcing to national research institutions can help
            enhance monitoring and evaluation and curtail shortcomings
            in classical State entities. These transfers permitted
            administrative directorates and schools to be in More
            attention to particular areas of concern, such as the
            financing of textbooks, should be given priority. charge of
            their own activities and to finance quality inputs.
